item.author: ccgasser@gmail.com (Camille Gasser)
item.description:
Exposure to novelty in everyday life boots long-term memory

Motivation

During the COVID-19 pandemic, lives were uprooted. Lockdown protocols and stay-at-home orders narrowed the scope of our worlds, sharply reducing the excitement and variety we experienced on a day-to-day basis. People began lamenting that their memory felt blunted or distorted, with days blurring together and very few moments standing out as vivid or memorable.

What might’ve caused this memory dysfunction?
item.content:encoded:
Exposure to novelty in everyday life boots long-term memory

Motivation

During the COVID-19 pandemic, lives were uprooted. Lockdown protocols and stay-at-home orders narrowed the scope of our worlds, sharply reducing the excitement and variety we experienced on a day-to-day basis. People began lamenting that their memory felt blunted or distorted, with days blurring together and very few moments standing out as vivid or memorable.

What might’ve caused this memory dysfunction?

Controlled experiments conducted in the lab suggest that, at least in some cases, we remember more novel events better than more typical ones. Memory also tends to benefit from more structure & variety in one’s experience, i.e., when there clear transitions between the different contexts we move through. (See this paper for more on this point!) For many of us, the pandemic reduced our exposure to both novelty and variety.

In this study, we wanted to test this link between novelty and memory outside of the lab and in the real world, asking the critical question: does having more novel experiences in everyday life lead to better autobiographical memory?

Research Design

For this study, we designed an intensive longitudinal “daily diary” study and recruited 50+ young adult participants to complete it. For two weeks, at the end of each day, each participant completed a daily survey (i.e., “daily diary”); they then completed a follow-up memory test another two weeks after the survey period.

All phases of the experiment were conducted remotely on Qualtrics, so participants could do each task conveniently on their phone, tablet, or computer.

During each daily diary, we asked a diverse set of questions about what the participant had experienced that day, including several metrics that tapped into how much novelty they were exposed to, such as:

  • whether they'd visited any new locations that day
  • whether they'd interacted with any new people that day
  • how typical or eventful they perceived their day to be

We also asked people to describe three specific events that had occurred on that day. For each event, the participant provided an open-ended text description of what happened during the event (e.g., what they saw, felt, did) and assigned the event a unique title. They also described the novelty of each event itself, labeling it as either:

  • "routine" (something they experienced almost every day);
  • "periodic" (something they experienced occasionally); or
  • "new" (something never experienced before)

Two weeks after the daily diary period, we tested participants’ memory for the specific events they had described, collecting both subjective and objective metrics of memory success.


With this survey design, we can look at how the novelty embedded in a person's everyday life is linked to the strength of their memory for personal experiences.

Analysis & Results

Before diving into the relationship between novelty and memory, we wanted to get a general sense of the amount of new experiences participants engaged in throughout the study.

As is clear from the plots below, although novel experiences were somewhat less frequent than more typical ones, they were hardly uncommon amongst our participants.

Next, we took a look at performance on the memory test, where we asked participants to try and recall the events they’d reported during each daily diary.

As briefly mentioned above, we had two measures of memory performance:

  1. memory vividness: a 1-5 rating reflecting how vivid the participant perceive their memory to be
  2. event recall: an open-ended text description of what the participant remembers about each event

The first of these measures is already numeric, and therefore was pretty straightforward to analyze. But in order to work with event recall, we needed to transform the recall text into a quantitative metric reflecting memory quality.

To do this, we took inspiration from existing audiobiographical memory scoring approaches and modern advancements in large language models (LLMs) and engineered a novel GPT-4 prompt that was able to segment each text description into individual “chunks” — each of which represents a discrete piece of information contained in the recall (e.g., a person who was present, an action that was taken). Applying this prompt to each recall description allowed us to quantify the number of unique details participants remembered about each event.

With recall scoring done, we could take a look at memory performance in our sample. Memory vividness ratings spanned the full 1-5 spectrum in a relatively uniform distribution, and most people recalled about 5-10 per event.

These two metrics — vividness ratings and number of details recalled — were also strongly correlated with each other, suggesting that participants’ subjective sense of the strength of their memories tracked closely with how much they actually remembered.

Now comes the critical question: was memory impacted by the novelty present in participants’ lives?

Our analyses highlighted two key results:

  1. More novel experiences were remembered more vividly and in greater detail than more typical events.

Events that were described as "new" during the diary period were remembered better than those that occurred "periodically", which in turn were remembered better than those that were "routine."

  1. Doing something new boosted memory vividness for other events that happened on that day, even if those other events weren't novel themselves.

We found evidence for this claim through two analysis approaches. First, we ran a multilevel linear regression model where memory performance (vividness or details recalled) was predicted by all of the novelty-related variables we collected during the diary period. This analysis showed that some of these novelty-related variables — like visiting a new location or interacting with a new person on the same day an event occurred — led to better memory, even when controlling for the novelty of the event itself.

Next, we filtered the data to look only at routine and periodic events and contrasted memory performance based on whether those events occurred on the same day as a novel event. This analysis showed that non-novel events that happened on the same day as a new event were remembered more vividly than those that did not.

Conclusions & Next Steps

Key Findings:

  • Novel autobiographical experiences were remembered more vividly and in greater detail than those perceived as more typical.
  • The mnemonic benefit of engaging in a new experience extended across time, such that other events reported on the same day as a novel event — and/or on the same day as visiting a new location or interacting with somebody new — were also better remembered.

These findings show the powerful and widespread effect that novelty has on our memory function, while also validating effects that have been observed in more controlled laboratory paradigms.

Next Steps:

  • Manuscript documenting this project is currently in progress.
    • In the meantime, check out Chapter 3 of my dissertation to read a full write-up of the study background, procedures, analyses, and results.
  • Ongoing analyses are exploring how variety in day-to-day activities — rather than novelty itself — impacts memory retention.
  • The research team also plans to replicate these effects in a larger sample, while also expanding the age range of recruited participants to examine if the effects of novelty change across age.

item.author: ccgasser@gmail.com (Camille Gasser)
item.description:
The decline & recovery of MTA ridership during COVID-19

data source: Metropolitan Transportation Authority (via Maven Analytics)
tools: R (ggplot, ggiraph)

This page includes all code used to manipulate, analyze, and visualize this dataset.

Introduction

The onset of COVID-19 uprooted almost every aspect of everyday life. As lockdown orders took effect, those who could stayed at home rather than venture out for work or fun. In New York City, this manifested as a dramatic reduction in usage of all MTA services — from the subway to buses to the bridges and tunnels that connect each borough.
item.content:encoded:
The decline & recovery of MTA ridership during COVID-19

data source: Metropolitan Transportation Authority (via Maven Analytics)
tools: R (ggplot, ggiraph)

This page includes all code used to manipulate, analyze, and visualize this dataset.

Introduction

The onset of COVID-19 uprooted almost every aspect of everyday life. As lockdown orders took effect, those who could stayed at home rather than venture out for work or fun. In New York City, this manifested as a dramatic reduction in usage of all MTA services — from the subway to buses to the bridges and tunnels that connect each borough.

The goal of this data exploration is to understand how MTA ridership was impacted by COVID-19 — and how it has since recovered.

First, let’s load in our data.

Set up workspace & load data 
 1library(tidyverse)
 2library(lubridate)
 3library(car)
 4library(cowplot)
 5library(ggiraph)
 6library(DT)
 7library(kableExtra)
 8
 9plot_theme <- theme_light() +
10  theme(panel.grid = element_blank(),
11        strip.background = element_rect(fill = 'grey30'),
12        panel.spacing = unit(1, 'lines'))
13theme_set(plot_theme)
14
15### load data
16mta_data <- read.csv('datasets/MTA_Daily_Ridership.csv', stringsAsFactors = F)
17mta_dict <- read.csv('datasets/MTA_data_dictionary.csv', stringsAsFactors = F)
18
19### rename columns & fix date formatting
20mta_data <- mta_data %>%
21  mutate(Date = as.Date(Date))
22colnames(mta_data) <- c('date', 'Subway_current', 'Subway_pre', 'Bus_current', 'Bus_pre', 'LIRR_current', 'LIRR_pre',
23                        'MetroNorth_current', 'MetroNorth_pre', 'AccessARide_current', 'AccessARide_pre',
24                        'BridgesAndTunnels_current', 'BridgesAndTunnels_pre', 'SIRailway_current', 'SIRailway_pre')

The dataset we start with

date Subway_current Subway_pre Bus_current Bus_pre LIRR_current LIRR_pre MetroNorth_current MetroNorth_pre AccessARide_current AccessARide_pre BridgesAndTunnels_current BridgesAndTunnels_pre SIRailway_current SIRailway_pre
2020-03-01 2212965 97 984908 99 86790 100 55825 59 19922 113 786960 98 1636 52
2020-03-02 5329915 96 2209066 99 321569 103 180701 66 30338 102 874619 95 17140 107
2020-03-03 5481103 98 2228608 99 319727 102 190648 69 32767 110 882175 96 17453 109
2020-03-04 5498809 99 2177165 97 311662 99 192689 70 34297 115 905558 98 17136 107
2020-03-05 5496453 99 2244515 100 307597 98 194386 70 33209 112 929298 101 17203 108
2020-03-06 5189447 93 2066743 92 289171 92 205056 74 30970 104 945408 103 15285 96

Original Data (scroll left/right to see full table)

Then we have to probably do something else.

Transform data 
 1# to get the actual ridership pre-pandemic:
 2#   current ridership = pre ridership * pre %
 3#   pre ridership = current / pre %
 4
 5# when pre % = 0, it's impossible to estimate original ridership
 6# this happens ~50 times with the SI railway, but nowhere else
 7# just removing these datapoints for now
 8
 9# sum(mta_data$SIRailway_pre == 0)
10
11mta_data_long <- mta_data %>%
12  pivot_longer(cols = c(ends_with('current'), ends_with('pre')),
13               names_to = c('service', '.value'),
14               names_pattern = '(.*?)_(.*)') %>%
15  mutate(pre_estimate = ifelse(pre != 0, current / (pre / 100), NaN)) %>%
16  pivot_longer(cols = c('current', 'pre_estimate'), names_to = 'timepoint', values_to = 'traffic') %>%
17  rename(pre_percentage = pre) %>%
18  mutate(year = year(date), .after = 'date') %>%
19  mutate(month = month(date), .after = 'year') %>%
20  mutate(day = day(date), .after = 'month') %>%
21  group_by(service) %>%
22  ungroup()
23
24# pull out proportion of traffic pre-pandemic
25service_pre <- mta_data_long %>%
26  filter(timepoint == 'pre_estimate') %>%
27  group_by(service) %>%
28  summarise(service_traffic = sum(traffic, na.rm = T)) %>%
29  ungroup() %>%
30  mutate(total_traffic = sum(service_traffic, na.rm = T),
31         service_prop = service_traffic / total_traffic)
32
33# look at proportion of traffic by service by post-pandemic year
34service_year <- mta_data_long %>%
35  filter(timepoint == 'current') %>%
36  group_by(year, service) %>%
37  summarise(service_traffic = sum(traffic, na.rm = T)) %>%
38  ungroup() %>%
39  group_by(year) %>%
40  mutate(total_traffic = sum(service_traffic, na.rm = T),
41         service_prop = service_traffic / total_traffic)
42
43# combine
44serivce_year_wpre <- service_pre %>%
45  mutate(year = 2026) %>% # setting pre-pandemic estimates as 2026 for plotting purposes
46  rbind(service_year) %>%
47  mutate(time_bin = ifelse(year == 'pre-pandemic', 'pre', 'curr'))
48
49# set factor level order
50mta_data_long$service <- factor(mta_data_long$service, levels = c('Subway', 'Bus', 'BridgesAndTunnels', 'LIRR',
51                                                                  'MetroNorth', 'AccessARide', 'SIRailway'))
date year month day service pre_percentage timepoint traffic
2020-03-01 2020 3 1 Subway 97 current 2212965
2020-03-02 2020 3 2 Subway 96 current 5329915
2020-03-03 2020 3 3 Subway 98 current 5481103
2020-03-04 2020 3 4 Subway 99 current 5498809
2020-03-05 2020 3 5 Subway 99 current 5496453
2020-03-06 2020 3 6 Subway 93 current 5189447

Reformatted Data

What was the share of traffic by service before the pandemic? Did it change?

Get traffic estimates by year 
 1# look at proportion of traffic pre-pandemic
 2service_pre <- mta_data_long %>%
 3  filter(timepoint == 'pre_estimate') %>%
 4  group_by(service) %>%
 5  summarise(service_traffic = sum(traffic, na.rm = T)) %>%
 6  ungroup() %>%
 7  mutate(total_traffic = sum(service_traffic, na.rm = T),
 8         service_prop = service_traffic / total_traffic)
 9
10# look at proportion of traffic by service by post-pandemic year
11service_year <- mta_data_long %>%
12  filter(timepoint == 'current') %>%
13  group_by(year, service) %>%
14  summarise(service_traffic = sum(traffic, na.rm = T)) %>%
15  ungroup() %>%
16  group_by(year) %>%
17  mutate(total_traffic = sum(service_traffic, na.rm = T),
18         service_prop = service_traffic / total_traffic)
19
20# combine
21serivce_year_wpre <- service_pre %>%
22  mutate(year = 2026) %>% # setting pre-pandemic estimates as 2026 for plotting purposes
23  rbind(service_year) %>%
24  mutate(time_bin = ifelse(year == 'pre-pandemic', 'pre', 'curr'))

Then plot the data!

 1g <- ggplot(data = serivce_year_wpre, aes(x = year, y = service_prop, fill = service, alpha = time_bin,
 2                                          tooltip = sprintf('%s: %.2f%%', service, service_prop * 100))) +
 3  geom_bar_interactive(stat = 'summary', width = 0.8) +
 4  theme(legend.position = 'right') +
 5  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'inferno', direction = -1, begin = 0.1, end = 0.9) +
 6  scale_alpha_discrete(range = c(1, 0.6), guide = 'none') +
 7  labs(x = 'year', y = 'proportion of total traffic',
 8       caption = 'hover over the plot to see percentages') +
 9  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(2020, 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2026),
10                     labels = c('2020', '2021', '2022', '2023', '2024', 'pre-pandemic')) +
11  plot_theme +
12  theme(text = element_text(size = 14),
13        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 11, face = 'italic'))
14
15girafe(ggobj = g, options = list(opts_sizing(rescale = T, width = .7)))
 1ggplot(mta_data_long, aes(x = date, y = pre_percentage, color = service, fill = service)) +
 2  geom_line(color = 'grey80', linewidth = 0.2) +
 3  geom_smooth(method = 'lm', linewidth = 2, alpha = 1) +
 4  geom_hline(yintercept = 100, linetype = 'dashed', color = 'tomato2') +
 5  facet_wrap(~service, nrow = 2) +
 6  scale_color_viridis_d(option = 'inferno', direction = -1, begin = 0.1, end = 0.9) +
 7  scale_fill_viridis_d(option = 'inferno', direction = -1, begin = 0.1, end = 0.9) +
 8  labs(x = 'date', y = 'percentage of pre-pandemic traffic') +
 9  plot_theme +
10  theme(text = element_text(size = 14), legend.position = 'top') +
11  guides(color = guide_legend(nrow = 1))

item.author: ccgasser@gmail.com (Camille Gasser)
item.description:
Interactions between motor behavior & episodic memory

quick links:
GitHub repository
(analysis code)
OSF page
(all study materials)
research paper
(published in Psych Science)

Motivation

Our lives are full of familiar & repetitive behaviors: commuting to work, getting ready for bed, typing out an email. But these routines don’t exist in a vacuum. Alongside our actions, we face a constant influx of sensory experiences, many of which might be useful to store in long-term memory.
item.content:encoded:
Interactions between motor behavior & episodic memory

quick links:
GitHub repository
(analysis code)
OSF page
(all study materials)
research paper
(published in Psych Science)

Motivation

Our lives are full of familiar & repetitive behaviors: commuting to work, getting ready for bed, typing out an email. But these routines don’t exist in a vacuum. Alongside our actions, we face a constant influx of sensory experiences, many of which might be useful to store in long-term memory.

Despite the collision of learning and behavior in everyday life, almost all research on memory treats motor actions as little more than a confound — something included in experiments just to keep subjects from getting too bored. So, as a PhD researcher, I posed a new question:

How does engaging in familiar behaviors affect our ability to form new episodic memories?

Research Design

To get at this question, I designed and built an original experimental paradigm that 180+ participants completed online. Each participant played a virtual memory game where they had to “run errands” through two different stores.

These errands involved two parts:

  1. visiting a sequence of aisles (by pressing buttons on the keyboard)
  2. collecting a sequence of objects (by viewing each object for a few seconds)


↑
click to try!

Participants visited two different stores during the experiment. In one of these stores (“predictable”), the sequence of aisles was always the exact same — and participants memorized this sequence before the errands began. In the other (“variable”), the aisle sequence changed on each errand.

In this way, we created two learning contexts (or conditions): one where motor behavior during learning was consistent and familiar, and another where it was not. Aside from this distinction, the two contexts were identical. And note that our experiment made use of a within-subjects design, where all participants ran errands in both of the stores.

After participants ran their errands, we tested their memory for the items they collected in each store, looking at three different kinds of memory:

  • memory for the order that items were collected during an errand
  • memory for the aisle that each item was collected from
  • memory for the individual items themselves (i.e., their unique perceptual details)

For each test, the primary output variable was memory accuracy, or the proportion of correct responses each subject made throughout the experiment. We then looked at the difference in memory accuracy for items collected in the predictable vs. variable store, allowing us to see the effects of familiar behavior on memory.

Our hypothesis was that memory accuracy would be better for items from the predictable store — because in this store, participants could "anchor" the novel items to the familiar sequence of actions.

Results

Across our three experiments, we found that executing predictable behaviors during learning did indeed promote episodic memory. And interestingly, this benefit was specific to memory for the order of items within an errand — not for their visual features or aisle they had been collected in.

The selectivity of this memory enhancement suggests that participants aren’t simply paying better attention to everything that happens in the predictable store. Instead, following a familiar sequence of actions seems to specifically boost memory for the sequential structure of concurrent experience.

To explore the results yourself, check out the interactive Shiny dashboard below.

Key Outcomes

This project sits at the intersection of research on episodic memory and motor learning — two topics in cognitive psychology that have historically been studied in isolation. The novel finding that familiar behavior can enhance concurrent encoding suggests that there might be more cooperation between these learning systems than was once assumed. In the future, it might be possible to take advantage of this cooperation, designing therapeutic interventions for people who have dysfunction in one memory system, but not others — like what occurs in Alzheimer’s.

For now, these findings simply highlight the important point that the actions we take throughout the day interact with the memories we create along the way.

This research was:

  • published as a peer-reviewed manuscript in Psychological Science
  • presented at multiple international scientific conferences (e.g., Society for Neuroscience Annual Meeting)
  • used as pilot data for a successful $90K+ grant from the National Institutes of Health (NIH)

Research Process Overview

item.title: Research Portfolio
item.author: ccgasser@gmail.com (Camille Gasser)
item.description:
Interactions between motor behavior & episodic memory

Series of novel online experiments revealing that engaging in well-learned actions during learning improves long-term memory.

key tools & methods: R, statistical analysis, data visualization, online experimentation, dashboarding

Exposure to novelty in everyday life boots long-term memory

Intensive longitudinal survey study demonstrating that doing new things as part of everyday life — going to new places, talking to new people — has strong and widespread benefits for autobiographical memory.
item.content:encoded:
Interactions between motor behavior & episodic memory

Series of novel online experiments revealing that engaging in well-learned actions during learning improves long-term memory.

key tools & methods: R, statistical analysis, data visualization, online experimentation, dashboarding

Exposure to novelty in everyday life boots long-term memory

Intensive longitudinal survey study demonstrating that doing new things as part of everyday life — going to new places, talking to new people — has strong and widespread benefits for autobiographical memory.

key tools & methods: R, Qualtrics, survey design, statistical analysis, data visualization, longitudinal research
